content.body: Is there any other markup language that has anything equivalent to an html table's ability to have overlapping cells?
..which I should consider while writing a schema language that can specify that a table should not have overlapping cells?

Or can you think of a case where anyone would be likely to create a markup language with a structure different from:  All cells are in rows, all rows must be the same width, all columns must be the same height, and there must be no overlapping cells?
I realize cells could be contained in columns instead... do you think that will ever happen?
Darxus: Have you ever used GridBagLayout?
Dashiva: No.
Darxus: hmm
well, someone might write a markup language where you had to lay out the table both in columns and rows separately
and if the two don't match up, it's an error
Heh.
Darxus: Microsoft Excel has the ability to merge (span) cells; other spreadsheet formats likely have the same ability
so OOXML and ODF
oh, *overlapping*?
that is, two cells that actually cover the same area?
deltab: http://www.chaosreigns.com/code/dxschema/tests/invalidtable.html
ah, not that I know of
deltab: Just looking for stuff I might want to be able to validate.  I think I've decided to not worry about it.
Implimenting relax ng style <choice> is difficult while my girlfriend is watching bollywood.
MikeSmith: why .../markup-spec/ and .../markup/? what's the difference?
Hixie: I don't know what markup-spec is
in dev.w3.org?
http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup-spec/
looks
man, between the media thing from philipj earlier and this navigation thing from bz, i'm getting no peace in terms of dealing with the simple stuff today
those are like 2 of the most complex algorithms in the spec, and both pieces of feedback are basically "there's this minor edge case that affects everything that you got wrong"
Hixie: you should just do what most other standards editors do, hide your head in the sand and don't admit those cases actually even exist
boy would that be nice
actually this fragment id thing might not be as bad as i feared
(the one i checked in earlier for media selection was a bitch, i'm sure i made mistakes in changing it)
that's the thing -- just like product dev: You make a fix in one place, risks introducing regressions elsewhere
yeah. i hate it when people say "oh i'm not asking for any normative changes, i would just like you to change your use of the word "foo" for the word "bar" everywhere"
how about... no
house of cards
man, I really don't know what I did to bring http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup-spec/ into existence. it's not in CVS. must be some apache redirect I set up and forgot about
heh
it's a different date
I'll get it figured out
by the way:
about comments saying there's no easy way to get a view of maturity levels of different parts of the spec
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/toc-status.html
that's something DanC set up a long time back
I made some tweaks to it yesterday
neat
it's generated from the annotations db
it uses the live data? sweet
we should link to it from somewhere
yeah
man i need to update the data on some of these
this is good, cos it shows an overview
would be nice to make it editable, if you have a spare 2 days :-D
I may have some time to mess around with it. I'm supposed to be on vacation for the next couple of weeks
man, there really isn't anything interesting in tv shows these days
i wish BBC and C4 were on iTunes in the US
BBC America is months behind and has the worst selection
would imagine you could get DVDs at least
DVDs aren't instant-play, and are region-locked, and aren't out yet for shows that are playing now anyway
i want to see today's Have I Got News For You, e.g.
or Top Gear
or Channel 4 News
and why is TNG not on iTunes? And why do the DVDs cost such an absurd fortune?
adds Red Dwarf to the list of BBC shows he wishes were on US iTunes
it's so sad that I could probably get a better experience if i used bittorrent
yeah
i mean, how hard can it possibly be to take my money?
i was tempted to watch the last season of BSG, but $60?! for a DRM'ed download? are you kidding me?
and charging $2 for 15 minutes of daily show when i can see it with ads on the comedy central site is ridiculous
hey, people pay $3 for ringtones. or pay ridiculous per-message fees for SMS that have no relationship to the actual costs
i don't
in Japan, we deal with the SMS cost thing just by not having SMS
the SMS thing is so absurd as to be laughable
yeah, massive boondoggle
and charging more for cropping a track than you paid for the track in the first place?
i mean, hello?
I ALREADY OWN THE MUSIC
you don't need to charge me to allow the file to be used in another app

I had figured that most content providers would have gotten past their greed and ass-backwardness by now and figured out they could be making a lot more money by pricing content reasonably and making it easier for people to get.
but I'm wondering if they will ever actually wise up
i'm really shocked that basically nobody in the TV industry has yet wised up to this stuff
i mean, national boundaries are obsolete
why are we still doing things by country
Maybe in 2022 you'll have time to spec Westphalia5
Hixie: the status indicators on http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/toc-status.html are now edit links
the ADD ones don't work yet; "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot call method 'appendChild' of null"
I assume because the script in the edit-section.html page isn't designed to be called this way
it seems to work OK for existing annotations, except that the edit-section.html page doesn't give any visual indication after you click Save
I guess it could redirect to the referring page
anyway, maybe not best to be using it this way
was just trying the quick-and-dirty approach first
Hixie: do you have the API for status.cgi documented?
wondering what the possible values for action are
other than action=get-all-annotations
nm
finds it in the code
